responses: I'm truly sorry about what happened to you. There are important medications that can help after an assault, including emergency contraception (Plan B/morning-after pill) and post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV prevention. These work best when taken as soon as possible - emergency contraception within 3-5 days and PEP within 72 hours. Please contact your nearest emergency room, sexual assault treatment center, or call a crisis hotline right away for proper care. They can provide these medications and other important services like evidence collection if you choose. You deserve support and care.

I'm so sorry you're going through this. After a sexual assault, there are medication options that may be important: emergency contraception to prevent pregnancy (most effective within 3-5 days) and post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) to prevent HIV (must start within 72 hours). The sooner you receive medical care, the more options you'll have. Please consider going to an emergency room, sexual assault treatment center, or calling a crisis hotline immediately. They can provide these medications along with compassionate care, testing for STIs, and evidence collection if you choose. Remember this wasn't your fault, and help is available.

responses: Emergency contraception (EC) can prevent pregnancy after sexual assault and works best when taken as soon as possible. Plan B One-Step and similar pills are most effective within 72 hours (3 days), though some types work up to 5 days after assault. EC is available at emergency rooms, health clinics, pharmacies (often without prescription), and sexual assault treatment centers. Side effects are typically mild. Please seek medical care immediately as healthcare providers can offer the most appropriate option based on your situation and timing. Sexual assault treatment centers and ERs typically provide EC at no cost to survivors.

After an assault, emergency contraception can help prevent pregnancy. The most common type (Plan B/morning-after pill) works best within 72 hours but may be effective up to 5 days. Ella (ulipristal acetate) is effective up to 5 days. These are available at emergency rooms, sexual assault centers, clinics, and pharmacies (Plan B is typically available without prescription). If more than 5 days have passed, please still consult a healthcare provider as other options may be available. Most ERs and assault treatment centers provide EC at no cost to survivors. The sooner you take it, the more effective it will be.

Should I take HIV medication after being assaulted?
responses: Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) can prevent HIV infection after sexual assault, but must be started within 72 hours (3 days) to be effective. It's a 28-day course of antiretroviral medications. The sooner you start, the more effective it is. PEP is available at emergency rooms, sexual assault treatment centers, and some urgent care facilities. For assault survivors, PEP is often provided at no cost, and assistance programs exist if needed. Please seek medical care immediately, even if you're unsure about your assault risk. Healthcare providers will assess your situation and recommend appropriate care.

HIV prevention after assault requires Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP), which must be started within 72 hours (3 days) after the assault. This medication significantly reduces the risk of HIV infection when taken as prescribed. PEP is a 28-day course of medications and is available at emergency rooms, sexual assault centers, and some HIV clinics. Side effects may include nausea, fatigue, and headaches, but these are typically manageable. Seeking care as soon as possible is crucial, as PEP becomes less effective with each passing hour. Most hospitals can provide PEP to assault survivors regardless of insurance status or ability to pay.

responses: After sexual assault, healthcare providers typically offer preventative antibiotics for common STIs like chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomoniasis. They may also provide vaccination or medication for hepatitis B and tetanus if needed. These preventative treatments work best when started soon after the assault. Additionally, a healthcare provider will likely recommend follow-up STI testing after 2 weeks and again after 3 months. Even if you receive preventative treatment, follow-up testing is important. Most emergency rooms and sexual assault treatment centers provide these medications at no cost to survivors.

To help prevent STIs after sexual assault, healthcare providers can offer preventative antibiotics for bacterial infections like chlamydia and gonorrhea. They might also recommend hepatitis B and tetanus vaccines if your immunizations aren't current. These treatments are most effective when started soon after the assault, but can still be helpful within days. Even with preventative treatment, follow-up testing is important—typically at 2 weeks, 6 weeks, and 3 months after the assault. Most sexual assault treatment centers and ERs provide these medications at no cost. Please seek medical care as soon as possible for the most comprehensive prevention options.

responses: For pain management after sexual assault, over-the-counter medications like ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) or acetaminophen (Tylenol) can help with soreness and discomfort. Applying ice packs (wrapped in cloth) to bruised areas for 15-20 minutes several times a day may reduce swelling. Warm baths with Epsom salts can also provide relief. However, please seek medical attention for severe pain, bleeding, or significant injuries. A healthcare provider can properly assess injuries, document them if you choose, and prescribe stronger pain relief if needed. Physical discomfort typically improves within days, but healing varies for each person.

Physical pain after sexual assault should be taken seriously. For mild to moderate discomfort, over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen can help. For external injuries, gentle cleaning and antibiotic ointment can prevent infection. Ice packs (wrapped in cloth) can reduce swelling, while warm baths may soothe general soreness. However, it's strongly recommended to seek medical care even if injuries seem minor, as some injuries may not be immediately apparent. A healthcare provider can properly assess, treat, and document injuries if needed. If you experience severe pain, bleeding, difficulty walking or urinating, dizziness, or nausea, please seek emergency medical care immediately.

How thorough is the medical exam after sexual assault?
responses: A sexual assault forensic exam (sometimes called a 'rape kit') is thorough but guided by your consent at each step. The exam typically includes a medical history, a head-to-toe examination documenting injuries, collection of evidence from your body and clothes, STI testing, and providing preventative medications. A specially trained nurse or doctor conducts this exam, which usually takes 3-4 hours. You can stop, pause, or skip any part of the exam. It's helpful to avoid showering, changing clothes, or brushing teeth before the exam if possible, but medical care is still beneficial even if you have. You can bring a supportive person with you, and many hospitals have advocates available. Getting an exam doesn't require you to report to police.

The medical examination after sexual assault is completely voluntary and consent-based. A sexual assault nurse examiner (SANE) or other trained provider will explain each step and ask permission before proceeding. The exam typically includes: a private conversation about what happened (only medically relevant details), documentation of injuries, collection of evidence if within 120 hours (5 days) of the assault, STI testing, and preventative medications. While parts may be uncomfortable, the examiner will be gentle and respectful. You can request breaks, skip parts of the exam, or stop completely at any time. Evidence can be collected even if you're unsure about reporting to police, and can be stored while you decide. Many facilities have advocates who can stay with you during the exam for support.

What should I expect at follow-up appointments after sexual violence?
responses: Follow-up medical care after sexual assault is important for your health. A typical schedule includes: 1) A follow-up within 1-2 weeks to check on injuries and medication side effects, 2) STI testing at 2 weeks, 6 weeks, and 3 months after the assault, 3) A pregnancy test 2 weeks after assault if emergency contraception was used, 4) HIV testing at 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months if PEP was not taken. Additionally, seek immediate medical attention if you experience fever, increasing pain, unusual discharge, bleeding, or new symptoms. Many sexual assault treatment centers will help coordinate these follow-up appointments. If you're taking PEP for HIV prevention, you'll need monitoring for medication side effects throughout the 28-day course.

Medical follow-up after sexual assault helps ensure your physical healing and addresses any developing health concerns. Generally recommended follow-up includes: checking healing of any injuries after 1-2 weeks, STI testing at 2-3 weeks and again at 3 months, pregnancy testing 2 weeks after the assault if relevant, and HIV testing at 6 weeks, 3 months, and sometimes 6 months. If you're taking PEP (HIV prevention medication), you'll need additional appointments to monitor for side effects and possibly blood tests to check organ function. Always seek immediate care if you develop symptoms like fever, unusual discharge, increasing pain, bleeding, or other concerning symptoms. Many sexual assault treatment centers offer follow-up care or can refer you to appropriate providers for ongoing care.

What helps with PEP side effects after sexual assault?
responses: Medications provided after sexual assault can cause temporary side effects. Emergency contraception may cause nausea, fatigue, headaches, or changes to your next period. Anti-nausea medication can be provided if needed. PEP (HIV prevention) commonly causes fatigue, nausea, and headaches in the first week, which typically improve as treatment continues. STI prevention antibiotics may cause stomach upset or diarrhea. To manage side effects: take medications with food (unless instructed otherwise), stay hydrated, use over-the-counter pain relievers if approved by your provider, and get extra rest. Contact your healthcare provider if you experience severe nausea/vomiting, high fever, unusual pain, rash, or symptoms that prevent you from taking your medications. Don't stop taking prescribed medications without consulting your provider.

Side effects from post-assault medications are common but usually manageable. Emergency contraception may cause nausea, breast tenderness, fatigue, headache, or changes to your next menstrual cycle. PEP (HIV prevention medication) often causes nausea, fatigue, headache, and sometimes diarrhea in the first 1-2 weeks. Antibiotics for STI prevention might cause stomach upset, diarrhea, or vaginal yeast infections. To minimize discomfort: take medications with food (unless directed otherwise), stay well-hydrated, rest when possible, and ask your provider about over-the-counter options for symptom relief. Contact your healthcare provider immediately if you develop severe vomiting, rash, fever, yellowing of skin/eyes, dark urine, or severe abdominal pain. These medications are important for your health, so don't discontinue them without medical consultation, even if experiencing side effects.

responses: Pregnancy concerns after sexual assault are understandable. Emergency contraception is highly effective when taken promptly (up to 95% if taken within 24 hours), but no method is 100% guaranteed. The earliest you can reliably test for pregnancy is about 14 days after the assault or a few days after a missed period. Most home pregnancy tests are accurate by this time. If your period is more than a week late, or if you experience pregnancy symptoms (nausea, breast tenderness, fatigue), consider testing. If you discover you're pregnant, know that you have options and time to make decisions that are right for you. Healthcare providers, sexual assault centers, and reproductive health clinics can provide confidential support, information about all options, and referrals to appropriate services. Many sexual assault centers can connect you with compassionate counseling to help process your feelings and make informed decisions.

After sexual assault, concerns about pregnancy are normal. While emergency contraception significantly reduces the risk of pregnancy (especially when taken within 72 hours), it's still important to follow up with pregnancy testing. A home pregnancy test can be accurate about 14 days after assault or around the time of your expected period. For the most accurate results, consider testing first thing in the morning. If your period is delayed by a week or more, or if you experience symptoms like nausea, breast tenderness, or unusual fatigue, testing is recommended. If you discover you're pregnant, remember you have time to consider all options, and there are resources to support you regardless of your decision. Sexual assault centers, women's health clinics, and reproductive health providers can offer confidential counseling, information, and referrals. Many areas have specialized advocates who can support survivors through pregnancy-related decisions after assault.

What if my injuries from assault aren't improving?
responses: It's important to have injuries from sexual assault evaluated by a healthcare provider, as some injuries may not be immediately obvious. For visible injuries: clean minor cuts with mild soap and water, apply antibiotic ointment to prevent infection, use cold packs (wrapped in cloth) for 15-20 minutes several times daily to reduce swelling and bruising, and take over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen for discomfort. Seek immediate medical attention for large wounds, heavy bleeding, severe pain, difficulty urinating or walking, dizziness, or any concern about internal injuries. Most minor cuts and tears heal within a week, while bruises may take 2-3 weeks. Follow-up care is important to ensure proper healing. If you notice increasing pain, swelling, unusual discharge, or signs of infection (redness, warmth, fever), seek medical care promptly.

Healing from physical injuries after sexual assault requires both proper care and time. While minor external injuries can be managed with gentle cleaning, antibiotic ointment, and over-the-counter pain relievers, a medical evaluation is strongly recommended even if injuries seem minor. Healthcare providers can identify less obvious injuries and provide appropriate treatment. For genital or rectal injuries, sitz baths (sitting in warm, shallow water) can provide relief, and avoiding tampons, sexual activity, and tight clothing can help healing. Most minor genital/rectal tears heal within 1-2 weeks. For bruising, applying cold packs in the first 48 hours followed by warm compresses can speed healing. Warning signs that require immediate medical attention include: difficulty urinating or having bowel movements, fever, increasing rather than decreasing pain, heavy bleeding, foul-smelling discharge, or expanding redness around wounds. Follow any specific instructions provided by your healthcare provider.

What evidence is collected in a sexual assault exam?
responses: Medical documentation after sexual assault creates a detailed record of your physical condition, injuries, and medical treatment. This documentation typically includes written descriptions, body maps marking injuries, and sometimes photographs (with your consent). This serves several important purposes: ensuring appropriate medical care, establishing a timeline of injuries and healing, and potentially providing evidence if you choose to report to law enforcement now or later. Medical records are kept confidential under privacy laws. Only you, your healthcare providers, and those you explicitly authorize can access them. Hospitals typically maintain these records for 7-10 years or longer, depending on location. You have the right to request copies of your medical records. If you might consider reporting to police in the future (even if not immediately), medical documentation can be valuable support for your case. However, receiving medical care doesn't obligate you to report the assault.

Medical documentation after sexual assault creates an objective record of your injuries, treatment received, and evidence collected. Healthcare providers document injuries through written descriptions, diagrams, and photographs (only with your explicit consent). This documentation is important for your medical care and can be valuable if you decide to make a police report, even if that decision comes later. Evidence collected during an exam can include DNA samples, clothing, photographs of injuries, and detailed descriptions of findings. This information is kept confidential under medical privacy laws. You control who has access to these records beyond your healthcare providers. Many jurisdictions now preserve evidence even if you're undecided about reporting, allowing time to make that decision. If you're concerned about privacy, ask the facility about their documentation policies, including how records are stored, who can access them, and how you can obtain copies. Remember that you can receive medical care even if you decline evidence collection or documentation.
